awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Design of Diffusiophoresis Processes for Drinking Water
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this STTR Phase I project will be to improve water purification with a new process offering reduced costs. Currently 1.8 billion people worldwide drink feces-contaminated water, of whom half a million die from waterborne diarrhea annually. The proposed technology also will reduce capital costs in more developed areas as it eliminates the need for pumps and filtration membranes.  The modular nature of the process equipment makes it scalable, from the modest requirements of isolated rural communities not served by distribution networks to the largest-scale throughputs of utilities serving major cities. 

This technology advances new methods for drinking water purification leveraging new research in fluid mechanics and electrokinetics. The suitability for drinking water purification of a diffusiophoresis process needs to be proven in the presence of complex chemistries representative of water streams with multiple dissolved impurities, and for the removal of colloidal contaminates, including bacteria. Experimental results spanning a range of parameters need to be obtained and tested against mathematical models, to establish design rules for scale-up. A laboratory experimental program, supplemented by mathematical modelling for quantitative understanding, aims to: (1) establish process feasibility and latitude in practical, ‘multi-ion’ environments; (2)map device dimensions, particle characteristics, water chemistries, particle removal efficiency, CO2 required; (3)demonstrate removal of colloids such that membranes will be at minimum significantly ‘unburdened’, and of bacteria such that chemical treatment can safely be at minimum significantly reduced; (4) determine process parameters and values for varying colloidal and microorganism loads.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Princeton University School of Mech. & Aerospace Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The process of CO2-based diffusiophoresis for separation of suspended colloidal particles from water without the use of a filter has been demonstrated in earlier fundamental research.  Dissolved CO2 supplied to one side of a flowing aqueous stream produces a transverse chemical gradient of ions that drives suspended particles to the other side of the stream. The Phase 1 program aimed to evaluate and to transfer laboratory work toward a commercially viable process with a potential first customer. The work contained both market and technical components (exploring and evaluating technical-market fit). At the end of the Phase 1 program, we had narrowed down the applications to drinking water treatment and a potato wastewater treatment.

In particular, as part of the grant we (i) demonstrated that diffusiophoresis with CO2 migration occurs in the presence of complex chemistries, across a wide range of particle sizes, and at large particle loading, (ii) designed a scaleup module that has scaleup viability toward pilot and manufacturing scale designs through parallel processing and we were able to advance from processing 10 μL per day to a design that can sustain up to at least 7 liters per day, (iii)  explored design and processing parameters pertaining to the scaled-up design to understand process and engineering potential of its separation performance, and (iv) evaluated diffusiophoresis process for potato wastewater treatment.

From our Phase 1 investigation, we conclude that the scaled-up CO2-based diffusiophoresis process is unlikely to achieve sufficient log reduction in particle densities to be commercially viable in the applications we studied. After thorough investigation of design and engineering parameters, we found the scaled-up process to be limited by the physicochemical phenomenon such that there is very little engineering latitude to achieve particle reduction necessary for drinking water treatment or to be competitive with commercially available microfiltration membranes. Also, our investigations led us to conclude that CO2-diffusiophoresis is an unlikely commercial candidate for potato wastewater processing. Thus, based on our evaluation of the CO2-based diffusiophoresis process in the context of these two applications, we have decided not to pursue a Phase 2 proposal.


Last Modified: 04/03/2023
Modified by: Howard A Stone

The process of CO2-based diffusiophoresis for separation of suspended colloidal particles from water without the use of a filter has been demonstrated in earlier fundamental research. The Phase 1 program aimed to evaluate and to transfer laboratory work toward a commercially viable process with a potential first customer. The work contained both market and technical components (exploring and evaluating technical-market fit). At the end of the Phase 1 program, we had narrowed down the applications to drinking water treatment and a potato wastewater treatment.

From our Phase 1 investigation, we conclude that the scaled-up CO2-based diffusiophoresis process is unlikely to achieve sufficient log reduction in particle densities to be commercially viable in the applications we studied.
